runs.text: Have students listen to the sound on the Articulation Video. Then display the Sound-Spelling Card schwa
/É™/. Explain that the schwa sound is pronounced uh, as in the second syllable of
. This sound can be spelled with any vowel
. Sound out the word, and have students repeat. Point out that when a multisyllabic word begins with
as the first syllable, the letter
makes the schwa, or uh, sound. Sound out the word, and have students repeat.
Guide students to read the words
(Add words with skills your students need to review.)
Use the first two words in the first line.
What do you hear thats the same in these two words? What do you see thats the same?

Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having student repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Display the graph on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card schwa /É™/. Review the following spellings and words:
Have students write the schwa spellings several times on paper or a dry-erase board. Prompt them to say the /É™/ sound each time they write the spelling.
Use the modified Lesson 1 blending words (with additional review words) to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Write the high-frequency words one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Discuss known and unknown word parts.
What sounds do you hear in
? (/h/ /a/ /f/) What letters to you see? (h-a-l-f) The letter
is silent, so we have to remember that when we spell the word.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Read Aloud: Why Do Schools Have Summer Vacation?
Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
. Review the following spellings and words:
spellings several times on paper or a dry-erase board. Prompt them to say the
sound each time they write the spelling.
Use the Lesson 2 blending words to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
When completed, guide students to find and circle all the words beginning with
. Then have them put a box around all the words with suffixes.
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequences of words.
low, slow, slowly; snow, snowy (cumulative review)
State the Letter Card to change. For example, say:
to the beginning. What word did you make?
Repeat, but dont tell students which letter to change. For example, say:
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequences of words.
. Review the following spellings and words:
Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.
When completed, have students select two words.
Ask them to write on paper or a dry-erase board a sentence for each word.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Guide students to slowly clap and say the syllables in
and focus on the spelling of each part of the word separately.
Dictate the following words for students to spell:

. Write the words on the board for students to self-correct. Note on each students Student Observation Form sound-spellings they struggle with. Include more words with these sound-spellings in upcoming lessons.
. Read each one and have students repeat. Explain that some nouns have irregular plural forms.
. Explain that it does not follow the pattern of just adding
, so it is an irregular plural noun.
Continue by writing the plurals of the following nouns:
Guide students to read each word.
Display each word, and guide students to read it.
Model how to sort the words
Have student partners sort the remaining words at their seats.
When completed, have students tell you how to sort the words in the pocket chart. Then have students chorally read the words in each column of the sort.
Ask students what they notice about the words.
If necessary, point out that the
sound can be spelled multiple ways.
Encourage students to look for words with /É™/ while reading. Highlight these words as you encounter them.

Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card schwa /É™/. Review the following spellings and words:
Have students write the schwa /É™/ spellings several times on paper or a dry-erase board. Prompt them to say the /É™/ sound each time they write the spelling.
Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Then discuss key features of each word to focus students attention on known (regular) and unknown (irregular) word parts.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.

spellings several times on paper or a dry-erase board. Prompt them to say the
sound each time they write the spelling.
Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Read, Build, Write: ago, government, half, machine, pair, quickly, scientist, thousand, understood, wait

Display the word cards. Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud. Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Extend the learning with one or more of the following activities:
Provide a sentence starter or frame for each word. Have students write and complete the sentences. Then have them read their sentences to a partner (e.g., The dishwasher is a machine that _____.).
Make a word using Letter Cards. Have students read and spell aloud the word. Then mix the Letter Cards. Have students fix the spelling.
. Review the following spellings and words:
spellings several times on paper or a dry-erase board. Prompt them to say the
sound each time they write the spelling.
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. When completed, guide students to find and circle all the words with schwa
. Then have them put a box around all the irregular plural nouns.
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequences of words.
State the Letter Cards to change. For example, say:
to the beginning. What word did you make?
Repeat, but dont tell students what letter to change. For example, say:
Read Aloud: Benefits of Thrift Shopping
Display the photo on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card schwa /É™/. Review the following spellings and words:
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to quickly review the skill.
When completed, have students select two words.
Ask them to write a sentence for each word on paper or a dry-erase board.
Revisit the sentences to model sentence expanding by adding details. Have students expand one of their sentences.
Read Aloud: From Ice Pits and Ice Boxes to Refrigerators
Display the illustration and photo on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
. Read each one and have students repeat. Explain that some nouns have irregular plural forms.
Have students build irregular plural nouns for the following words:
Have students select two of the irregular plural nouns from the list and write sentences for them.
This word names a big African cat with a mane.
lemon to name a toy with wheels that you can pull.
wagon to name a large bird of prey
falcon to name something a cook or baker wears around his or her waist.
apron to name something you tie around a gift.
Read, Build, Write: ago, government, half, machine, pair, quickly, scientist, thousand, understood, wait
Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud.
Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Mix the Letter Cards, and have students rebuild it as they point to and say the letters.
